fields: Organization Setup covers the basic settings that need to be reviewed and completed before starting an implementation, such as the {{c1::default time zone}}, {{c2::language}}, and {{c3::currency}}.

An administrator also needs to be aware of what additional information can be found within this section of setup, such as {{c1::data storage}}, {{c2::file storage}}, {{c3::license counts}}, and {{c4::API usage}}.
Default locale configuration impacts the format of the {{c1::time}}, {{c2::date}}, {{c3::number}}, {{c4::phone number}}, and {{c5::address}} fields.
Business and holiday hours impact the {{c1::calculation to determine when to escalate a case}} or {{c2::when an entitlement milestone is reached}}
Fiscal year options can be defined as either {{c1::standard}} or {{c2::custom}}.
{{c1::Standard fiscal years}} are based on a monthly structure and can start on any month. {{c2::Custom Fiscal years}} can use different structures such as quarters.

Salesforce offers a number of {{c1::fully supported}}, {{c2::end user}} supported,  and {{c3::platform only}} languages. 
The language on the company settings page is applied to {{c4::new users}}, but it can be overriden in My Settings.
The API (Application Programming Interface) is a way of accessing Salesforce {{c1::programmatically}} and is used by {{c2::Data Loader and Integration tools}}.
The organisation ID is a {{c1::unique 15 character}} identifier that identifies each Salesforce organisaiton and is different in each environment.
The time zone for new users is set using the {{c1::default time zone}} on the Company Settings page, but users can override it in My Setttings.
{{c1::Multi-currency}} is used to be able to add amounts in different currencies on records and be able to forecast and report using the {{c2::corporate currency}} or {{c3::record currency}}.
Advanced currency management allows {{c1::dated exchange rates}} to be recorded to track the amounts when opportunities were closed.
There are {{c1::user licenses}}, {{c2::feature licenses}} and {{c3::permission set licenses}}.
Salesforce has two categories of storage: {{c1::Data Storage}} (used by records), and {{c2::File Storage}} (used by attachments, documents, files, content and chatter).
Under {{c1::My Settings}}, users can set their own time zones to override the organisational default.
{{c1::Fully supported languages}} means all Salesforce features, including User Interface, Setup, and Help, will display in the selected language.
{{c1::End User supported langues}} will have translations for all standard object field labels and pages but not Setup and Help.
For {{c1::Platform supported languages}}, it is possible to provide translations for customizations and standard fields. If translations are not provided, labels fall back to English.

Fully supported languages are available for selection for the default organization language or user display language, but other languages {{c1::must be enabled}} in Language Settings before they can be selected.
User licenses define the {{c1::baseline of features}} available to a user. Each user must be assigned one license
Feature licenses grants access to {{c1::additional features}} that are not included in a standard license, such as Marketing, Knowledge, or CRM content.
{{c1::Permission set licenses}} grant users access to features that are not included in their user licenses.
The number of API requests that can be made in a <u>24 hour period</u> are based on {{c1::edition and number of user licenses}}.
Salesforce API <u>is available</u> for {{c1::Enterprise}}, {{c2::Unlimited}}, and {{c3::Performance}} editions.
A {{c1::System administrator}} can <u>enable</u> multi-currency and currencies must be made {{c2::active}} for them <u>to be used.</u>
The {{c1::primary currency}} reflects either the default corporate currency or the currency selected for the record.
The {{c1::secondary currency}} reflects the personal default currency of the user running the report, or the currency specified in the report criteria.

Most records use {{c1::2KB}} of storage. There are several exceptions: {{c2::Person Account}} (4KB), {{c3::Campaigns}} (8KB), {{c4::Articles}} (4KB), and {{c5::Email Messages}} (storage according to the size of the email).
Salesforce Enterprise edition provides {{c1::10GB}} of data storage plus 20MB (or 2GB) per user license.

If an org utilizes big objects, up to {{c1::1 million big object}} records can be stored. Additional capacity can be purchased via licenses to store more (a {{c2::billion}} or more) big object records.
{{c1::Holidays}} <u>only</u> influence {{c2::case escalation rules}}.
{{c1::Custom fiscal years}} impacts forcasting, quotas, and reports.

ACME Corp is making the switch to Lightning Experience. The administrator is tasked with creating different pages to fulfill business requirements. What pages are available to create with the Lightning App Builder?
Home Page, App Page, Record Page, Email Application Pane

{{c1::Global search}} searches <u>most</u> information; {{c2::List View Search}} looks for a record 
<u>within a list view</u>;  {{c3::Lookup search}} allows searching of <u>related records 
from a lookup field</u>.
The user interface settings control {{c1::General User Interface}}, {{c2::Sidebar (Classic Only)}} and {{c3::Calendar}}.
An {{c1::enhanced lookup}} offers search on all fields, sort, filter, customize columns, page navigation, auto completion

The following {{c1::search settings}} can be enabled/customised: Number of search results displayed, Document Content Search, Recently Viewed Records, Search Optimization, Limit search to records owned by the user.
In the {{c1::list view}}, actions such as Edit, Delete and Follow records, Sort, Filter, Create Printable View are available.
Different types of search layouts include: {{c1::Search Results}}, {{c2::Lookup Dialog}}, {{c3::Lookup Phone Dialog}}, {{c4::Tab}}, {{c5::List View}}, and {{c6::Search Filter Fields}}
{{c1::Links}}, {{c2::Images}}, {{c3::HTML}}, and {{c4::Visualforce}} custom components can be added to the home page layout.
A user can look for a company in the List View using keywords by using the {{c1::List View Search Bar}} at the top of the List View.
The {{c1::search results layout}} of the Knowledge object can be customized to include Lightning Knowledge fields in global search results in Lightning Experience.
Results can be {{c1::filtered}} by number range for list views in Lightning Experience to allow users to view opportunities that fall within a {{c2::certain amount or probability range}}.

A Lightning component on a home page can be made visible to only users from a certain country by setting a {{c1::component visibility filter}} in the {{c2::'Set Component Visibility' section}} of the component's properties in the Lightning App Builder.
The {{c1::App Manager}} is used to view, create,and customize apps available in the organization.
{{c1::System Administrators}} can personalize their Salesforce apps and match some aspects of their company’s branding
The {{c1::Utility Bar}} allows easy access to common productivity tools such as Notes, History, Calculator and Omnichannel.
Items placed in the Utility Bar will appear near the {{c1::bottom}} of the screen. It can be set to display on either the left or right of the screen.
{{c1::Temporary tabs}} are opened when a user clicks an item that does not have a parent object placed in the navigation bar.
Temporary Tabs appear in the navigation bar with an {{c1::asterisk}}.
Temporary Tabs may be made a permanent part of the navigation bar by selecting {{c1::‘Add to Nav Bar’}} from the dropdown arrow.
{{c1::In-App guidance}} can be used to create a hands-on interactive tour to guide users through onboarding or feature introduction by means of step-by-step prompts.
A {{c1::direct link}} for prompts and walkthroughs can be sent to users or can be attached to the help menu or help documents.
The {{c1::Search Layout}} determines which fields users can view, filter on, and sort by on the search results page for global search and lookup search.
{{c1::Search personalization}} can be enabled to customize searches based on factors such as recent user activity, geographic location where users work most often, and ownership.
Themes and branding does not apply to {{c1::mobile}} interface.
{{c1::Encrypted, formula, and lookup}} fields cannot be searched.
{{c1::Standard}} users cannot customise the Search Results layout.
{{c1::Sharing rules}} cannot be used to restrict access to records. Access to a Lightning App can be configured based on the {{c2::profile}} of a user, but not by their {{c3::role}}.

The Admin can navigate to the {{c1::'App Menu'}} page in Setup and drag the apps to change their order. They can also click 'Visible in App Launcher' or 'Hidden in App Launcher' to show or hide individual apps in the App Launcher for all user in the org.

Each Salesforce User has their own {{c1::user record}} on which personalized settings are established. All users must have a profile assigned, which determines their {{c2::access}} to objects in addition to what {{c3::privileges}} they have.
On an individual user record, {{c1::user licenses}} are assigned. Additional {{c2::feature licenses}} can be assigned for items such as Marketing, Knowledge or Mobile User (the Salesforce app).
Once a user is established, administrators can assist with {{c1::resetting passwords}}, {{c2::unlocking}}, or {{c3::freezing}} user accounts on individual user records.
Users are permanent records that cannot be deleted. Instead, the options are to {{c1::deactivate}} the users or to {{c2::freeze}} users.
While creating a new user, user details such as {{c1::Last Name}}, {{c2::Email}}, {{c3::Username}}, {{c4::User License}}, and {{c5::Profile}} are required.
The {{c1::user license}} determines the level of access to the org and what profile can be selected for a particular user.
A {{c1::feature license}}, such as Salesforce CRM Content User, provides access to additional features not included with the user license.
A password can be reset by a user or administrator. Unlike a user, administrators can reset passwords for {{c1::multiple users}}.
A user’s account that has been locked due to too many failed attempts to access can be unlocked by {{c1::an administrator}}.
Various locale settings, such as {{c1::language}}, {{c2::time zone}}, and {{c3::currency}}, can be specified on a user’s record.

User set up is as follows:
  • {{c1::User details}}
  • {{c2::User license}}
  • {{c3::Feature license}}
  • {{c4::Role}}
  • {{c5::Profile}}
  • {{c6::Localisation}}

To complete the setup process, the following steps need to be done:
  • {{c1::Account verification link}} is sent via email
  • {{c2::Password}} is created
  • {{c3::Security question}} is created
{{c1::Usernames}} are unique across all Salesforce organizations globally and consequently cannot be reused.
{{c1::Usernames}} must be in email format, but do not need to be valid email addresses

An email will be sent to the new user that contains the account verification link. By default, the link will expire after {{c1::7 days}}. The account verification link will prompt the new user to set a new password. If the user fails to set the password before the link expires, the user will need to have the password reset by the {{c2::admin}} before they can log in.

Before an admin-initiated email update is approved, a user can be required to change their password by enabling the {{c1::‘Generate new password and notify user immediately’}} setting. A password reset link is sent to the new email address to activate the new email address.
Multiple users (up to {{c1::10}}) can be added at one time.
Users can be created in batch by using the {{c1::Data Loader}} application

The {{c1::Login History}} page provides information on past login attempts to the org. The {{c2::Status column}} will indicate success or reason for failure to login. It shows up to {{c3::20,000}} login records for the past {{c4::6 months}}.

{{c1::Freezing}} a user record can be used when steps to deactivate a user are incomplete. It is an {{c2::immediate}} action that prevents them from logging in and having access. No emails or Chatter alerts will be sent.
Freezing a user does not release their license. To release the license the user must be {{c1::deactivated}}.

{{c1::Deactivating}} a user disables them from logging in and having access to Salesforce. They will no longer get any email or Chatter alerts. Use this only on users who should no longer have access to the organization.
Users cannot be {{c1::deactivated}} if they are the sole recipient of a Workflow Email Alert, Customer Portal Administrator, default lead or case owner, or User selected in a Custom Hierarchy Field.
{{c1::Administrators}} can log in as any user in the Setup menu under Login Access.

Common user access issues:
  • Passwords are {{c1::case sensitive}}
  • Users may be trying to login outside of the {{c2::login hours}}
  • Using an inaccurate {{c3::username}}
  • Logging into an incorrect {{c4::domain}}
  • Using an {{c5::unverified}} account
  • The user is locked out as a result of too many {{c6::failed login attempts}}
  • {{c7::IP restrictions}} may be in place and user is outside of the given set

The {{c1::setup audit trail}} history helps to track the recent setup changes that administrators have made to the org. If there are multiple administrators in the org, this is of great help in keeping a record of the changes.
If a delegate (such as an administrator or customer support representative) makes a setup change on behalf of an end user, the {{c1::Delegate User column}} shows the delegate’s username.
Setup audit trail by default shows {{c1::twenty}} most recent setup changes and stores audit trail history for the past {{c2::six months}}.

An administrator can configure several settings to ensure that users’ passwords are strong and secure:
  • Password {{c1::policies}}: can't contain username or the first/last name, minimum length, security question, reusing passwords.
  • Password {{c2::expiration}}: how long a password is valid for.
  • Password {{c3::resets}}
  • Login attempts and {{c4::lockout}} periods
{{c1::Single Sign-On}} allows users in the org to login to Salesforce and other applications using credentials with an external identity provider.
{{c1::Multi-factor authentication}} increases an org’s security by requiring a second level of authentication for every user login.
{{c1::Session Timeout Settings}} can be configured to log out inactive users after the specified length of time.
{{c1::Device activation}} is invoked when a user logs in from an unrecognized browser or device, and is logging in from outside a trusted IP range.

Verification is done via the highest priority verification method available in the following order:
  • Salesforce {{c1::Authenticator Mobile App}}
  • U2f {{c2::Security key}}
  • {{c3::OTP}} generator
  • {{c4::SMS text message}}
  • {{c5::Email}}
{{c1::View All and Modify all}} grants access to all records of the object and overrides sharing settings.
{{c1::Profiles}} determine which objects a user can access and what actions they can take on those objects.
{{c1::Object permissions}} control what users can do with records they own.
{{c1::Organization-Wide Defaults}} determines access to other users' data for records they do NOT own.
{{c1::Sharing rules}} open up record access to users when the OWD settings are set to anything more restrictive than Public Read/Write.
Individual records can be manually shared using the {{c1::‘Sharing’}} button.
{{c1::Field-level security}} controls visibility to data within records at the field level.
The {{c1::role hierarchy}} grants access to records to users that have a role above the record owner in the role hierarchy.
The {{c1::‘Sharing Hierarchy’}} button can be used to determine why a user has access to a record. It is available for accounts, opportunities, cases, contacts, leads, and custom objects.
What is the appropriate sharing model: Everyone should be able to see all opportunities, but only Managers should be able to see the Opportunity Value.

• Set OWD for opportunities to Public read.
  • Set the field level security for Opportunity Value to visible only for users with the Manager profile
What is the appropriate sharing model: Users work competitively and do not want to let other users see the information of their contacts.
Set the OWD for contacts to Private.
Select appropriate sharing model: Typically, no one should be able to see each other’s contracts, but users share on a record by record basis when needing help with re-negotiation.

• Set OWD to Private for contracts. 
  • Put the “Share” button on the contract page layout, and show users how to manually share the records

Select appropriate sharing model: The sales team should not see other’s opportunities, but their managers need to see everyone on their team’s opportunities. At the same time, Finance and the company president should have access to all opportunities.

• Set OWD for Opportunity to private.
  • Establish a role hierarchy. 
  • Have sales at the bottom, with managers in a role above them. 
  • Put finance above managers, and the president above all other roles.

Select appropriate sharing model: A company has many branches. Each of the branch’s employees are in a variety of roles, but need access to all customers owned by users from their branch. They should not be able to see customers from other branches

• Set OWD to private for customers. 
  • Create public groups for each branch. 
  • Create a sharing rule to share with that branch’s public group, if the owner is from that branch.

Select appropriate sharing model: An organization would like to allow its marketing department to be able to see only the details of the campaign members whose contact or lead records they have access to

Set the organization-wide default sharing setting for the Campaign Member object to 'Controlled by Campaign Member'. It would allow all users to see only the campaign members whose contact or lead records they have access to in Salesforce

Select appropriate sharing model: Users of an organization are currently only able to see campaign members whose lead or contact records they have access to in Salesforce. However, the Marketing Director would like them to access campaign member records only if they have access to the related campaign. Also, users belonging to a certain public group require access to all campaign members regardless of the default access.

• Set the organization-wide default sharing setting for the Campaign Member object to 'Controlled by Campaign'. It can be used to allow users to only be able to see campaign members if they have access to the campaign associated with them. 
  • Since the Campaign Member object would inherit sharing rules from the Campaign object, a campaign sharing rule can be created to give the public group access to all the campaigns, which would automatically give access to the related campaign member records

Select appropriate sharing model: A company uses a custom object to order supplies. Employees create order records in this custom object. The supply manager then manages the orders and maintains some fields that other employees should not have visibility to when they create the order records

• Field level security can be used to restrict access to these fields by users with a certain profile.
  • If field level security is not used, creating different page layouts is feasible. One page layout that contains all the fields can be assigned to the profile of the supply manager and the other page layout without the fields can be assigned to the profile of the employees. However, these fields can still be visible in reports, search results, or list views.

Select appropriate sharing model: The sales users of a company use only Lightning Experience to manage records such as accounts and opportunities. No sales user should be able to view the accounts owned by any other user in the company. However, sales managers, who are assigned to a certain custom profile, need the ability to share specific account records with certain users whenever required

The organization-wide default sharing setting of the Account object can be set to ‘Private’ to ensure that users can’t view accounts owned by other users. The ‘Sharing’ action can be added to a new Account page layout. This page layout can be assigned to the custom profile that is assigned to the sales managers to allow them to share account records manually in Lightning Experience

Select appropriate sharing model: Cosmic Gemina is a transportation company that has sales divisions in three countries, namely, France, Germany, and Italy. Each sales division has a sales manager who should be able to view and edit custom sales reports that have been created for their division.

Each sales manager should be granted the user permission of ‘Create and Customize Reports’ through a permission set, which would allow them to create, edit, and delete reports in private folders. They should also be given ‘Editor’ access to the report folder that contains their sales division’s performance reports. The ‘Editor’ access level would allow each sales manager to view, edit, save, rename, and delete the reports in the folder.

Select appropriate sharing model: The business intelligence officer of Cosmic Felix owns a report folder that contains various reports related to accounts and opportunities. He has shared this folder with certain sales representatives so that they can view these reports, but in the future, he would like a sales manager to share the folder with the sales representatives who require access to the reports. The sales manager already has the user permission to view and edit reports in shared folders.

For this requirement, the sales manager should be given ‘Manager’ access to the report folder. This access level should allow him or her to manage the reports and sharing settings of a particular report folder, which means he or she can share the folder with other sales representatives in the future

Select appropriate sharing model: Cosmic Formata recently implemented Salesforce and has various report and dashboard folders. There are various sales users from different departments who require access to them, but their level of access should depend on their roles and responsibilities

Public groups can be created for users based on their roles and responsibilities. Access to report or dashboard folders can be granted to each public group. For example, if users in a public group only need to view the reports within a particular report folder, then ‘Viewer’ access can be assigned to that public group

Select appropriate sharing model: Cosmic Hispana is a company in Spain that manufactures sports equipment. It uses various custom objects to store information about products and sales orders. Certain public dashboard folders have been created by the company’s administrator. These folders contain dashboards that display metrics related to these custom objects. An analytics manager should be able to create and edit dashboards in these folders and manage their sharing

The analytics manager should be granted the ‘Manage Dashboards in Public Folders’ permission for this requirement. It would allow him or her to create, edit, and delete dashboards, and manage their sharing in all public dashboard folders

All users in Salesforce are assigned a {{c1::profile}} that outlines which objects they can access and actions that can be performed on the objects. It also determines app access, IP restrictions, and various other permissions.

Certain profiles come out of the box and cannot be edited, but the administrator has the ability to create {{c1::custom profiles}} to meet needs. In addition to profiles, additional permissions and access can be granted through {{c2::permission sets}}.
A profile can be used to grant app, system, or custom {{c1::permissions}} to specific users within an organization.
A {{c1::permission set}} can be assigned to a user to extend the user’s settings and permissions granted by their profile.
A {{c1::custom profile}} can be created by cloning an existing profile. It can be fully customized based on security requirements.
{{c1::Standard profiles}} are existing profiles in an org which can be assigned to users and cloned but cannot be edited.
{{c1::App permissions}} control what actions can be performed in different apps, e.g., Call Center App and being able to use Live Agent.
{{c1::Custom permissions}} must be enabled, and they can be used to grant access to custom apps or processes.
{{c1::System permissions}} grant access to actions that are organization-wide, e.g., create report folders or use Chatter.
One Finance manager needs access to all opportunities. Opportunities are not included in the Finance profile
Grant access to opportunities through a permission set. It does not make sense to create a profile for one user. Permission sets can be used to grant access to objects and fields
The CTO would like to restrict the ability to create and customize reports to a certain group of users.

Create a custom profile by cloning the existing standard profile wherein the “Create and Customize Reports” permission should be removed. In addition, a permission set must be created to extend “Create and Customize Reports” permissions to the selected group of users.
Indentify appropriate action: Certain users should have the ability to import leads. They have different profiles depending on the department they are in.
Due to having different profiles, the administrator should create a permission set with the permission “Import Leads” and assign to appropriate users.

Select appropriate sharing model: The administrator is testing a new app with custom sales objects. Select users are helping to test the app as it is not ready for a general release to the entire org.

During the testing, a permission set granting access to the app and objects can be assigned to the specific users. The administrator can add more users to increase the test base as needed. Once it is ready for release, the access to the app and related components can then be added directly to the profile(s) to give access to users who need it

Select appropriate sharing model: A group of sales users who require access to Salesforce should be able to access activities and all the Chatter features in Salesforce. A few of these users should also be able to view the records of a custom object but not be able to access the records of any other object.

The sales users can be assigned to the Minimum Access - Salesforce profile, which is a least-privilege profile that grants the Access Activities, Chatter Internal User, Lightning Console User, and View Help Link permissions. A permission set can be assigned to the users who need to view the records of a custom object.

A custom profile needs to be created and assigned to the sales users of Cosmic Travels to give them access to certain administrative and user permissions. However, the Standard User profile that will be cloned for it provides the ability to access Quotes which have been disabled in the org. The administrator would like to ensure that any features or permissions that have been disabled or are not accessible to the org are not available in the new custom profile

To meet this requirement, the Restricted Profile Cloning option can be enabled in User Management Settings. This option ensures that only the permissions accessible to the org are enabled when a profile is cloned to create a custom profile. In the new custom profile, the permissions for the Quote object would be unavailable.
What checks are done when users try to access a Salesforce organisation?
Profile Level Login Hours, Profile Level IP Ranges, Company Level Trusted IP Ranges, Activation Code Validation
How does the security health check work?

Security Health Check measures setting values in Password Policies, 
Network Access Config and Session Settings against baseline values and 
calculates a percentage score to indicate risk. 100% means all settings 
meet or exceed the standard.
When is identity verification invoked?
When a user logs in from an unrecognized (based on cookies) browser or device, and outside the trusted IP range
What can be enabled that helps the administrator spot suspicious login activity?
Login Forensics
What are the different risk categories associated with a Security Health Check in Salesforce?
High, Medium, Low, and Informational
What password requirements can an administrator set?
Minimum password length, complexity, password history enforcement, expiration period, minimum password lifetime
Where can session security settings be configured at the organisation level and the profile level in an org?
On the ‘Session Settings’ page at the organization level and in a user profile at the profile level
Which session setting can be configured to log out inactive users in an org?
Session timeout
How is the role hierarchy related to record access?

Users will have access to other users' records if they have a role above
 the record owner in the role hierarchy and grant access through 
hierarchies is enabled.
What do organisation-wide default settings do?
Determine access to records the user does not own and sets base record access for the org.
How do Sharing Rules work?
Rules can be created to grant access to groups of users for certain records based on record owner or criteria.
What does field-level security control?
Controls if a field is visible or read-only at the profile level
What should be considered when changing OWD settings?

If increasing default access, changes will take effect immediately. If 
decreasing, changes may take significant time depending on data volumes.
What is Manual Sharing?

Manual sharing allows a user to use the ‘Sharing’ button to grant access
 to a specific record to other users, roles, roles and subordinates, 
territories, territories and subordinates, and public groups.
What is the purpose of a public group?
It’s a way of grouping users, roles, and territories so that sharing settings and permissions can be granted efficiently.
Which sharing setting allows a user to manually share their own user record with other users of an organisation?
'Manual User Record Sharing' checkbox on the 'Sharing Settings' page in Setup
Which OWD sharing setting can be used for the Campaign Member object to allow all users to see only the campaign members associated with the campaigns they have access to?
Controlled by Campaign
Which access level for a report folder would allow a user to change the folder's sharing setting?
'Manage'
Which folder access levels allow saving, deleting, and renaming reports or dashboards?
‘Edit’ and ‘Manage’
Which options are available for selecting the users while defining the access level for a report or dashboard folder?
The access level for a report or dashboard folder can be defined for a particular user, group, territory, or role.
Why would a user be freezed?

To prevent the user from logging in without deactivating them, allowing 
for changes to any customization where the user has been used (e.g. 
workflow email alerts)
What are some common user access issues?

– Wrong Username
– Entering password in wrong case
– User is locked
– Trying to login to a sandbox with the wrong URL
What can be done to immediately prevent a user that left the company from having any access to Salesforce?
Freeze the user record, then make the adjustments needed to deactivate.
What should be done when a user no longer needs to use Salesforce?
Deactivate the user record; users cannot be deleted.
What administration tasks can an administrator delegate?

Create and assign users in certain roles and profiles, assign 
permissions sets, public groups, reset passwords, manage specific custom
 objects
What field must be marked on the user record for users to be able to log in?
The “Active” checkbox
What is the minimum information required to setup a user?
Username, Last Name, Email, Profile, Alias, Nickname and License
What localisation settings apply to a user?
Locale, Language, Time Zone, and Personal Currency
How would it be possible to check why a user is not able to login?
Login history on user record, or Login History for all users will give information regarding a login attempt.
A maximum of {{c1::10}} users can be created at one time when using the Add Multiple Users function
Users cannot be deactivated if they are the sole recipient of a {{c1::Workflow Email Alert}}, {{c2::Customer Portal Administrator}}, or is {{c3::selected in a Custom Hierarchy Field}}

Default password policies are: user password expires in {{c1::90}} days, Salesforce remembers {{c2::3}} past passwords and the minimum password length is {{c3::8}} characters. A user is allowed {{c4::10}} invalid login attempts.
An Admin needs to create 200 users but he does not want to notify the users of their login details. What is the most efficienct way to ahcieve this?

The best way to create 200 users is with Data Loader. Users created with Data Loader will not have a password generated. After they have been loaded, the users can be selected from a User list view that you define and the password reset for all selected users from the view itself using the Reset Password button.

Health check grade in Salesforce is as follows:
  • 90% and above: {{c1::Excellent}}
  • 80%-89%: {{c2::Very good}}
  • 70%-79%: {{c3::Good}}
  • 55%-69%: {{c4::Poor}}
  • 54% and below: {{c5::Very poor}}
A user has left their phone at home which is usually used for multi-factor authentication. What can the Salesforce Admin do?
Generate a temporary verification code
If a user is working in Salesforce when the login hours end, what will happen?
The user can continue the page they are currently on, but if they take further action or navigate to a new page they will be logged out.
{{c1::Profiles}} and {{c1::permissions sets}} define object level permissions and not record-level access
Reports and dashboards are shared through {{c1::folders}}.
Only {{c1::Cases}} and {{c2::Leads}} have OWD sharing options of 'Public Read/Write/Transfer'.
There are two types of objects in Salesforce: {{c1::Standard}} and {{c2::Custom}}.
{{c1::Standard}} objects are pre-built in Salesforce, giving the org an initial data model.
Examples of standard objects include {{c1::Campaigns}}, {{c2::Leads}}, {{c3::Accounts}}, {{c4::Contacts}}, {{c5::Opportunities}} and {{c6::Cases}}.
{{c1::Custom}} objects are those that an administrator creates and defines specifically for a use case.
Both standard and custom objects come with standard fields but can be expanded with {{c1::custom fields}}.
These objects become part of a larger data model through {{c1::lookup fields}} and {{c2::master-detail}} relationships, connecting data within the org.
{{c1::Accounts}} can be created in Salesforce to store information about companies and individuals (person accounts).
A {{c1::contact}} in Salesforce represents an individual associated with an account.
A {{c1::lead}} is a prospect that can be converted into an account, contact, and opportunity.
The {{c1::campaign}} object is used to store information about a marketing event.
{{c1::Campaign members}} are individual contacts, leads or person accounts that are added to campaigns.
{{c1::Opportunities}} are used to store information about and track sales deals in progress.
{{c1::Cases}} can be created to track issues faced by customers.
A {{c1::solution}} is a detailed description of an issue faced by a customer and the resolution of that issue.
A {{c1::user}} record is created to uniquely identify a Salesforce user with a name, unique username, email address, user license, profile, role, and other settings.
Standard objects can be customised by {{c1::adding fields}} and {{c2::creating relationships}}.
{{c1::Master-detail}} relationships tightly relates two objects through a parent-child relationship. It can be {{c2::one-to-one}}, {{c3::one-to-many}} or {{c4::many-to-many}}.

{{c1::Lookup}} relationships is a loose relationship between objects. It links objects together so users can see related items from one object to another. It can be {{c2::one-to-many}}, {{c3::self}}, {{c4::external}}, {{c5::indirect}} or {{c6::hierarchical}}.

An {{c1::Account}} can be related to one or many {{c2::Contacts}}. Their relationship also holds the characteristics of both master-detail relationship and the sharing settings can be inherited from master to detail.

An {{c1::Account}} can be related to one or many {{c2::Opportunities}}, and an {{c2::Opportunity}}  can be related to only one {{c1::Account}}. However, it also behaves as a master-detail relationship since deleting an {{c1::account}} record deletes all the related {{c2::opportunities}}.
An {{c1::Account}} can be related to one or many {{c2::Cases}}, and a {{c2::Case}} can be related to only one {{c1::Account}}. {{c1::Account}} and {{c2::Case}} have a lookup relationship.
A {{c1::Contact}} can be related to one or many {{c2::Accounts}} (if {{c1::Contact}} to Multiple {{c2::Accounts}} setting is enabled)
A {{c1::Case}} can be related to one {{c2::Contact}} and a {{c2::Contact}} can be related to many {{c1::Cases}}. A {{c2::Contact}} has a lookup relationship to {{c1::Case}}.

A {{c1::lead}} can be converted into an Account, Contact and optionally an Opportunity. Information from the {{c1::lead}} is copied into the Account and Contact fields. Custom fields on the Account, Contact and Opportunity can be mapped to custom fields on the {{c1::Lead}}.
A {{c1::Campaign}} can have many {{c2::Campaign Members}}. A {{c2::Campaign Member}} can be related to either a Lead or a Contact.
{{c1::Schema Builder}} can be used to view the data model as well as create objects, fields, and relationships quickly.
{{c1::Relationships}} are used in Salesforce when there is a need to relate records in one object with a different object.
Salesforce supports the following types of relationships between objects: {{c1::lookup}} and {{c2::master-detail}}.

{{c1::Related}} records from a lookup or master-detail relationship can be seen through {{c1::related lists}} on the page layout. A {{c1::related list}} on the parent record displays {{c1::related}} child records.
{{c1::Lookup}} relationships does not inherit the sharing and security settings from another object.
A {{c1::self}} relationship can be created by creating a lookup to the same object, e.g. an Account with a lookup to another Account field.
Standard objects must be on the {{c1::master}} side of the relationship with a custom object.
Many-to-many relationships are implemented via the use of a {{c1::junction}} object. A {{c1::junction}} object sits between the other 2 objects and has a master-detail relationship with both.

Customisaton option for standard fields:
  • {{c1::Field labels}} can be changed.
  • Standard {{c2::picklist}} values can be added, renamed, reordered, deleted or deactivated.
  • {{c3::Field history}} tracking can be set.
  • Field-level {{c4::help}} can be added
  • {{c5::Lookup filters}} can be added or edited
  • {{c6::Auto-number}} field format can be adjusted
  • Can be removed from {{c7::page layouts}} to hide them from users
  • Cannot be {{c8::deleted}}

Custom fields can be created on standard and custom objects to store additional data:
  • {{c1::Data types}} can be set according to the requirement
  • {{c2::Fields}} can be set to required,which will require a value in the field before saving
  • Fields can be set as {{c3::unique}}, which will prevent duplicate field values.
  • Certain field types can have a {{c4::default value set}}. These include Check box, Currency, Date, Date /Time, Email, Number, Percent, Phone, Picklist, Text, TextArea, URL.
  • Text fields can be set as {{c5::case sensitive}} so that values, such as ‘abc’ and ‘ABC’, are treated as different values.
  • {{c6::Time}} fields can be used to track {{c6::time}} that is not specific to a single date, such as preferred contact hours. It is useful for time management, event planning, and project management
What are the steps to creating custom fields?

1. Select data type
  2. Enter details
  3. Set field level security
  4. Add to Page layouts
Field types of custom fields can be changed. {{c1::Data loss}} can occur in certain field type changes
{{c1::Picklists}} are predefined lists of values where users can select from.
A {{c1::restricted}} picklist means that only the values defined can be used. Other values cannot be inserted even via the API.
A picklist value can be {{c1::deactivated}}. This will not affect existing values.
If a {{c1::global value set}} is used, then the picklist is restricted.
{{c1::Multi-select}} allows multiple values to be selected.
If a {{c1::non-existing value}} is imported into an unrestricted picklist, it will be added only to the updated or created record but not in the picklist field value selection.
A {{c1::dependent}} picklist allows the values in one picklist to be filtered by the values in another picklist or checkbox field.
The picklist or checkbox that drives the filtering is called the {{c1::controlling field}}
The picklist that has its values filtered by the value selected in the controlling field is called the {{c1::dependent field}}.
A {{c1::dependent}} picklist can be multi-select. A multi-select picklist can only be a {{c1::dependent}} field.
{{c1::Standard}} picklist fields can be controlling fields but not dependent fields.
{{c1::Custom object}} picklist fields can be controlling or dependent.
{{c1::Roll-up Summary}} Fields are used to {{c1::‘roll-up’}} either the sum of the value of a particular field in the child object, return the min or max value or a count of the number of records
Roll-up summary fields are defined on the {{c1::master}} object and available for certain object relationships such as Standard >Custom, Custom > Custom, and certain standard relationships.

Calculating roll-up summary field values may take up to {{c1::30}} minutes, depending on the number of records affected and other factors. It can be performed manually by selecting the {{c2::‘Force a mass recalculation on this field’}} option on the edit page of the field.
{{c1::Formula fields}} are read-only fields that automatically calculate a value based on other fields or a {{c1::formula}}
Formula fields are {{c1::automatically updated}} when one of the fields used in the formula changes.
{{c1::Merge fields}} can reference fields in related objects, e.g., a custom formula field on Contact can reference a field from Account.
{{c1::Cross-object}} formulas can reference merge fields from two related objects for calculations that will be displayed on detail pages, list views, and reports.
{{c1::Simple}} formulas allow selection of fields from the same object and use of operators
{{c1::Advanced}} formulas allow selection of fields from the parent object and use of functions.
If a field is no longer required (either as it was created by mistake or it is not required any longer),it can be {{c1::deleted}}. When it is {{c1::deleted}}, the data is also removed

Deleted custom fields count against custom field allocation within {{c1::15}} days after deletion.Hard-deletion of deleted custom fields can be accelerated in order to free up custom field allocation.
If a field is {{c1::restored}}, it needs to be manually added back to page layouts and marked as required /unique again if needed.

After a field is restored, {{c1::field history}} is available again. If the field was part of a master-detail relationship, it will be restored as a {{c2::lookup}}. It needs to be converted to master-detail.
A custom field cannot be deleted if it is {{c1::referenced}} elsewhere in the application, e.g., field updates in a Workflow or Process Builder
A deleted field can be {{c1::restored}} if it has not been permanently deleted or within 15 days. After 15 days, Salesforce will permanently delete it.
{{c1::Record ID}} Field is a globally unique read-only system type field assigned to every object in Salesforce

A record ID is generated when the record is {{c2::created}}. Every record has its own {{c1::15}} character case-sensitive unique identifier. The API defaults to using {{c3::18}} character case-insensitive record IDs. This field is not displayed on the record detail page,but the ID can be found in the {{c4::URL}}.
{{c1::External}} IDs are fields that contain a unique identifier from a system outside of Salesforce.

For example, the ‘SAP AccountNumber’ field can be added to the Account object and mark it as an {{c1::external ID}}. When data is imported or integrated into the account object, records can be matched using the ‘SAP AccountNumber’ field instead of the record ID.
There can be up to {{c1::25}} external IDs on an object.
Up to {{c1::200}} custom objects can be created in Enterprise edition and up to {{c2::2000}} in Unlimited and Performance edition.
{{c1::Custom}} objects can be created to record custom data not covered by standard objects. A common example is Expenses.
The custom record name can be a {{c1::text}} field. It can also be {{c2::auto-number}}.
An {{c1::App}} is a collection of tabs made visible to certain profiles.
Salesforce comes with {{c1::standard}} apps, such as Sales, Service, and Marketing
{{c1::Custom}} Apps can be created, and the header can be customized for company branding
When creating a custom object, a new {{c1::tab}} must be created to be able to create records via the user interface.
{{c1::Web}} tabs will embed a web page within a Salesforce tab
{{c1::Page layouts}} control the layout and organization of fields, buttons, links, publisher actions, report charts, Visualforce, and related lists.
Page layouts allow fields to be marked as {{c1::read-only}} or {{c2::required}}.
{{c1::Sections}} can be used to organize fields on the page
Different page layouts can be assigned to different {{c1::profiles}} so that each type of user can see fields that are relevant.
The {{c1::mini page layout}} controls the fields that are displayed when hovering over a record
Fields displayed, sort order, and buttons in the related list can be controlled in the {{c1::page layout}}.

Beyond the customization of custom objects and custom fields, the administrator has the ability to control how objects and records are presented to users through {{c1::page layouts}} and {{c2::record types}}

A page layout controls what {{c1::fields}}, {{c2::related lists}} and {{c3::buttons}} show on a record. Record types control page layouts for different types of {{c4::records}} and can limit picklist values.
The administrator can build {{c1::business processes}} and {{c2::Paths}} to guide users through the stages of an opportunity or other objects.
{{c1::Record Types}} allow different {{c2::picklist values}}, {{c3::page layouts}}, and {{c4::business processes}} to be defined for an object, standard, or custom

These are the steps that a Salesforce Administrator would take when creating a new record type:
  1. Create {{c1::page layouts}} to be used for record types.
  2. Add any additional {{c2::picklist}} values.
  3. Create {{c3::record type}} record.
  4. Assign record type to {{c4::profiles}}.
  5. Assign {{c5::page layout}} for each profile for each record type.
  6. Select {{c6::picklist}} values for record type

Users can set a {{c1::default}} record type in their personal settings, so they are not prompted to select one when creating a new record. This option is only available when there are two or more active assigned record types on the user profile.

Record Types can be created for all Salesforce objects. For the following objects, a {{c1::business process}} must be first created before a record type: {{c2::Opportunities}}, {{c3::Cases}}, {{c4::Leads}}, {{c5::Solutions}}.
A {{c1::Business Process}} captures the lifecycle of leads, opportunities, cases, or solutions. It references a standard picklist field and the values can be customized
Business processes can be set up within Salesforce. These can be used to align with the organization’s existing processes. Only {{c1::Solution}} Processes is not available in Lightning Experience.
Recommend solution: Sales Reps should only take web leads for business customers. Individual customers must come through in-person contact
Create two record types, Business and Individual. Adjust the picklist for the Individual record type to remove Web as a lead source
Recommend solution: Both Eastern and Western Sales teams use Opportunities. Each team sells a different set of products and records the region in which the lead is based.
Create Eastern and Western Opportunity Record types. Adjust the product picklist to match each region's team. Also adjust region picklist so it only matches the regions that each team covers.
Recommend solution: Global Finances deals with US-based and foreign-based customers. There is a requirement to verify if contact information is in the correct format for the location

Create different fields for all the possible location information (i.e. US phone #, foreign # number, county field, prefecture, etc). Create different record types and page layouts for each country. Add the appropriate fields to each page layout. Assign the page layouts to the appropriate record type

Recommend solution: Smith Technologies handles technical and customer service cases. Technical cases are required to gather make, model and warranty info. Customer service cases don’t require these fields.
Create two page layouts, technical and customer service. Set required fields on technical page only. Create two record types, technical and customer service and assign page layouts

An international company has two active record types created for its customers and partners from different countries. They are available for all users with Account Executive user profiles but the Account Manager wants to set record types specifically for a number of Account Executive users to ‘Customer’ record type.
Configure default account record type for every designated Account Executives in their Personal Settings. Either the Account Executives can perform this step or the System Administrator

Sales reps use three active Lead record types: Contact Form, Cold Calling, and Customer. Sales Manager wants to assign Customer record type to be the default for all Sales Rep but still have the options to choose what record type to use when creating Leads manually.

In the Sales Rep Profile page, configure the default Lead record type to ‘Customer’ under the Record Type Settings section. This way, when Sales Rep users create new records, they will be prompted to choose from the available record types but will have the ‘Customer’ record type radio button automatically ticked.

Recommend solution: ABC Corporation has different sales processes for projects under $500k and those above. The projects above $500k should go through Finance and have more hands-on meetings with the customers, while those under the amount will not need this attention
Create a business process and set the stage list appropriately for projects under $500k and for those over $500k
For each stage on the Path, guidance and up to {{c1::five}} fields can be displayed.
To enable and create a Path, search for {{c1::Path Settings}} from Setup. When created, the Path will appear as a {{c2::Lightning Component}} to be placed on the page.
Campaign members can either be {{c1::Leads}} or {{c2::Contacts}}
Checking if a field is required is an example of wat type of validation?
System validation. It is performed before custom validation rules.
{{c1::Sales}} processes allow the definition of a custom set of {{c1::sales}} stages that an opportunity must pass through during the lifecycle from open to closed.

Salesforce offers various capabilities to support the sales process as an opportunity is in different stages, including {{c1::forecasting}}, {{c2::quotes}}, {{c3::splitting revenue}} amongst team members and {{c4::orders}}.
A {{c1::quote}} can be created from an opportunity and related products to generate proposed prices of the products for a customer.
Opportunity revenue or other opportunity currency fields can be {{c1::split}} among opportunity team members using opportunity {{c1::splits}}.
An {{c1::order}} is an agreement with a customer to provide products or services. {{c2::Reduction}} {{c1::orders}} can be used for cancellations, returns or {{c2::reductions}}
Collaborative {{c1::Forecasting}} can be utilized to predict sales revenue and quantities from the opportunity pipeline.
A {{c1::sales process}} can be created to define a custom sequence of {{c1::sales}} stages. It can be assigned to an opportunity record type.
{{c1::Opportunities}} are used to track sales deals in Salesforce. They advance through various sales stages until they are closed, won or lost.
{{c1::Opportunities}} track sales deals and are used to produce the sales forecast.
Opportunities advance through {{c1::sales stages}} tracking from open to closed / won or closed / lost.
{{c1::Stage}} is the key field to track the Opportunity as it advances.
Each stage is mapped to a type, defining whether an {{c1::Opportunity}} in that stage should be regarded as open or closed in reporting.
Each stage is mapped to a {{c1::probability}} which is used for calculating expected {{c2::revenue}}.
Each stage is mapped to a {{c1::forecast}} category which is used when displaying {{c1::forecasts}}.
If no Opportunity record types are defined, then all sales stage {{c1::picklist}} values can be selected
A sales {{c1::path}} can be configured for opportunity stages in Lightning Experience. It is a customizable visual representation that provides tailored guidance at each stage of the sales process.

{{c1::Expected Revenue}} is calculated by multiplying the amount by the probability percentage. When the opportunity stage changes, a {{c2::default}} probability value is set for that record. The probability field value can later be edited.
Sales {{c1::Processes}} can be used to define a custom series of sales stages.
To use a custom sales process, it is assigned to a {{c1::record type}}.

Suggest solution: MyPet Corporation launched a new line for its pet food products. The sales process for the new line is different from the existing sales process of the older product line as there will be additional sales stages to be added. What should the system administrator do to meet the requirements?
Create new opportunity stage values. Add in a new sales process and record type dedicated to the product line. Create a new path to display the stages on the record page
Suggest solution: For opportunities valued at over $100k, additional stages of financial background and manager approval are needed, but opportunities under $100k do not need these steps.
Set up 2 different record types based on the opportunity value. Assign each record type a different Sales Process, with the appropriate stages.
{{c1::Forecasts}} are a way of estimating revenue for products and services in the future based on Opportunities and their stages and values.
Before Forecasting can be used, Opportunity Stages are mapped to {{c1::Forecast Categories}}.
Forecast values are displayed in the different forecast categories, for example: {{c1::Pipeline}}, {{c2::Best Case}}, {{c3::Commit}}, {{c4::Omitted}} or {{c5::Closed}}.
Based on its stage, an {{c1::Opportunity}} is assigned to a Forecast Category. The standard values for categories are Pipeline, Best Case, Commit, Omitted, and Closed. These can be customized.
A forecast {{c1::type}} uses a specific type of data and determines how Salesforce calculates forecasts.

Up to {{c1::four}} forecast types can be enabled for Collaborative Forecasting. A setup flow is launched to create a new forecast type in ‘Forecast Types’. An {{c2::object}}, {{c3::measure}}, {{c4::date type}}, and {{c5::hierarchy}} can be selected for a forecast type.
Suggest solution: Management has asked to see the opportunities being worked on and the likelihood of closing to create the next year’s budget.
Set up Forecasting to create a pipeline for management.
In Salesforce, {{c1::Quotes}} are records that shows the proposed prices of the organization's products and services.
When a quote is created from an Opportunity, the Opportunity Products are {{c1::added to the quote automatically}}.
{{c1::Multiple}} quotes can be associated with an Opportunity.
A PDF can be generated for the quote using the {{c1::‘Create PDF’ button}}.
The layout and fields included in a Quote PDF can be adjusted by defining a {{c1::custom template}}.
Quote can be emailed using the {{c1::‘Email Quote’ button}} which will automatically attach the latest quote generated to the email.
Quote {{c1::syncing}} feature allows users to link a quote to the opportunity that it was created from and reflect updates made between the two records.
Quotes are {{c1::‘synced’}} with the Opportunity to update the Opportunity Products if any changes have been made to the quote or update the quote if any changes are made to the Opportunity Products
Only one quote can be the ‘syncing’ quote. Syncing is started by clicking the {{c1::‘Start Sync’ button}}.

Quote Syncing does not sync custom Opportunity fields with custom Quote fields or custom Opportunity line item fields with custom quote line item fields. For that requirement, you need an {{c1::AppExchange app}} or to write a {{c2::trigger}}.
Suggest solution: A customer is asking for pricing options, wanting to know prices for lower quality material and higher end materials.
Create two different quotes under the opportunity. Add the appropriate products to each quote

Opportunity {{c1::Splits}} allow opportunity revenue or other Opportunity currency fields to be split among the opportunity team members. It needs to be {{c2::enabled}}. When {{c2::enabled}}, a script will run to add an opportunity split record for the Opportunity owner with 100% split
Before enabling Opportunity Splits, {{c1::‘Team Selling’}} should be enabled first from the Opportunity Team Setup.
Salesforce adds two splits when enabled: {{c1::revenue}} splits and {{c2::overlay}} splits.

{{c1::Revenue}} splits is used to split the Opportunity amount field. The total percentage allocated to members must always be equal to {{c2::100%}}. Revenue splits will be used in revenue based forecasts.
{{c1::Overlay}} splits are based on the amount field. The percentage does not need to total to 100% and can be higher or lower.
Opportunity Splits can be added and edited from its own {{c1::related list}} under Opportunity.
Up to {{c1::6}} custom split types can be defined.
Splits can be defined on most opportunity currency fields, including custom {{c1::currency}} fields and {{c2::roll-up summary}} fields, but not {{c3::formula currency}} fields.
{{c1::Custom}} split types can be configured to be required to total 100% or not.
Suggest solution: The company uses account teams, and each member of the team should get the appropriate compensation based on their contribution to the opportunity.
Setup Opportunity splits so each team member gets credit.
An {{c1::order}} is an agreement to provide products or services to a customer at a certain quantity, price, and date.
Orders can be related to an Opportunity and Quote with {{c1::Lookups}}
An {{c1::order}} can be created from an Account, Contract or from the {{c1::order}} tab.
Orders can be associated with a {{c1::contract}} to track the fulfillment of the {{c1::contract}} agreement
Orders have status values. Default values are {{c1::‘Draft’}} and {{c2::‘Activated’}}.
Other status values can be added for an order. New values need to be {{c1::mapped}} to a status category of Draft or Activated.
Orders must be enabled in {{c1::Order Settings}}. {{c2::Reduction}} orders and allowing negative quantities can also be set.
A {{c1::Pricebook}} is an object that stores the list of products and their prices. To add products in Orders, a {{c1::Pricebook}} must be selected.
When an order has been reviewed and ready for shipment, it can be {{c1::‘Activated’}}.
If the order is associated with a {{c1::contract}}, the {{c1::contract}} must be activated before the order is activated.
{{c1::Reduction}} Orders are used to record cancellations, returns, or a reduction in order quantity.
An order can have {{c1::multiple}} reduction orders applied. A reduction order can only be applied to {{c2::one}} order.
In Salesforce, the {{c1::Contract}} object is used to define and document the {{c1::contracts}}, terms, or agreements associated with an order, account or opportunity
Suggest solution: A customer wishes to cancel part of their order they placed last week
Create a reduction order related to the original order.
Suggest appropriate action: The company sells specific products, not contracts, and they want to track what each customer orders.
Use the orders object under accounts to track the purchases

{{c1::Opportunity tools}} aid sales teams and management with creating an opportunity to closing it. Features such as {{c2::sales}} dashboards, {{c3::lead}} scoring, {{c4::opportunity}} scoring, and {{c5::assistant}} can be utilized by sales users to improve their productivity.
{{c1::Products}} and {{c2::Price Books}} allow {{c1::Products}} to be added to Opportunities and different price lists to be defined and selected for each opportunity.

{{c1::Email Alerts}} and {{c2::Update Reminders}} make sure no deal is missed and those that need it are kept up-to-date. {{c3::Team Selling}} allows defining users to be included on an Opportunity for collaboration and assistance.
Sales reps can use {{c1::Sales Dialer}} to access telephony features in Salesforce.
{{c1::Macros}} can be used to automate repetitive tasks, such as sending an email.
Sales {{c1::Console}} allows sales reps to work on multiple records simultaneously.
{{c1::Kanban}} view displays the opportunities in each stage of the sales process.
In Lightning Experience, a {{c1::path}} displays where an opportunity is in the sales process.
Opportunity notifications can be sent periodically or based on {{c1::triggers}}.
A {{c1::custom price book}} is a separate list of products with custom prices.
Each product has a default {{c1::standard}} price in the {{c1::standard}} price book.
The {{c1::list}} price of a product is its custom price in a custom price book.
The {{c1::sales}} price of a product is the price determined by a {{c1::sales}} representative.
The standard price book is the {{c1::master}} list of all the products and their standard prices
{{c1::Products Schedules}} can be used to determine the payment and delivery cycles for products.
{{c1::Products}} can be associated with opportunity, quote, order, or service contract
{{c1::Products}} are the items and services sold by a company and their standard prices.
{{c1::Custom dashboards}} can be created by accessing the Dashboards tab and clicking ‘New Dashboard’.
Dashboard {{c1::components}} are used to show report data in a different visual chart display.
The {{c1::source report}} for a dashboard component can be selected from the ‘Data Sources’ tab.
Different types of {{c1::dashboard components}}, such as chart, gauge, metric, table, and Visualforce page, can be used
All report formats can be used for dashboard components, but tabular reports must be limited by {{c1::row}}
A custom dashboard can contain various charts like {{c1::funnel}}, {{c2::donut}}, and {{c3::gauge}} charts.
A custom {{c1::URL}} that includes filter parameters can be created for a dashboard. The {{c1::URL}} can be accessed later to open the dashboard with the filters already set.
Lead {{c1::Score Calculation}} is accomplished by creating various custom fields for different factors and calculating them together to form a single value.
{{c1::Einstein Lead Scoring}} uses data science and machine learning to score leads based on the company’s successful conversion patterns.
{{c1::Einstein Opportunity Scoring}} gives each opportunity a score from 1 to 99
Einstein Opportunity Scoring is part of {{c1::Sales Cloud}} at no extra cost. Users with and without the {{c1::Sales Cloud}} Einstein license have access to opportunity scores.
The {{c1::Assistant}} is a standard Lightning component available for the Home Page that allows sales users to view important updates about their leads and opportunities over the course of the day
The Assistant shows up to {{c1::10}} updates at a time. Updates about {{c2::leads}} are displayed before updates about {{c3::opportunities}}

A maximum of {{c1::five}} Key Fields can be added to display the most important record data for the users. {{c2::Guidance}} is a space for tips, instructions, links, or company information that will help users succeed
A {{c1::Kanban}} visually displays Opportunities in each stage within a {{c2::List View}}.
A Kanban is also available on other standard and custom objects that have {{c1::picklists}}
The Macros {{c1::utility}} can be accessed in the {{c1::utility bar}} of the Lightning Sales console.
Quick Text, Email Templates, and Attachments can be used in {{c1::macro}} instructions.
In order to use the Macro Builder, the {{c1::Macro utility}} component should be added to the page.
{{c1::Pipeline Inspection}} provides sales managers greater visibility of their {{c1::pipeline}} by providing information on key metrics, opportunities, and weekly changes

The User must have {{c1::Read and Create}} object permissions on Products in order to create a new product item. A product can be created from the Products homepage or it can be {{c2::cloned}} from an existing product
A {{c1::revenue}} schedule can be used if customers make regular payments but receive the product once.
A {{c1::quantity}} schedule can be used if customers pay once but receive the product in increments.
Default {{c1::schedules}} can be defined for a Product and will be automatically established when a Product is added to an Opportunity.

Users can select any Price Books that they have {{c1::access}} to or {{c1::shared}} with them. Products can only be added from a {{c2::single}} Price Book. Changing a selected Price Book will delete all existing products from the {{c3::opportunity}}.
A single product can have {{c1::multiple list prices}} in different currencies
Price Book organization-wide sharing can be set to {{c1::Use}}, {{c2::View Only}} or {{c3::No Access}}
The {{c1::Big Deal Alert}} can be used to send notifications when an Opportunity of a certain value reaches a trigger probability and trigger amount.
{{c1::Team Selling}} must be enabled before Opportunity Splits can be used
Suggest solution: The Sales Team has complained about not having a way to view all opportunities sorted by stage. They want to see categories of stages and have the ability to quickly update.
Set up a Kanban view for Opportunities. This will allow users to see the records categorized, as well as quickly update with drag and drop.

Suggest solution: Your Sales Team handles hundreds of Opportunities at a time. They’ve requested an easier way to work through several records at once, vs using multiple browser tabs for each opportunity.
Set up a Sales Console. This will allow opportunities to be viewed within multiple tabs, gives them recent record views, as well as a utility bar, all allowing for quicker access to multiple records
Suggest solution: Your company has specific steps for each stage of an opportunity, with actions needing to be taken outside of Salesforce
Set up a Path on the opportunity. Mark key stages, and in the Guidance for Success, outline the actions to be taken outside of Salesforce.
Suggest solution: Your executive team wishes to be notified for any potential deals valued at over 1 million
Set up the Big Deal Alert. This will send notification to selected users (Executive team) when the amount of a deal is above threshold set
Suggest solution: Your Sales Team managers review their open opportunities reports daily to check statuses.
Setup Update reminders and all users with direct reports will be sent a nightly report.
Suggest solution: It is important for your business line to track who may win a deal if you don’t, and understand your strengths on opportunities.
Set up Competitors so each deal can have these listed, with the competitors strengths and weaknesses.
Suggest solution: Your Sales Team works together on deals, pulling in each users specialities for deals. It is most often the same group of users working together to close a deal
Set up Team Selling, allowing users to be added in for assistance to specific deals when needed

Suggest solution: The sales reps of an organization have to perform certain tasks in the Lightning Console for Sales repeatedly, such as updating opportunity records and sending emails to customers. The Sales Director is looking for a way to reduce the time spent by sales reps on such repetitive tasks.

The Macros utility can be added to the console app to allow reps to create and run macros that can automate repetitive tasks in the console. Macros work on all objects that support quick actions and have a customizable page layout

Suggest solution: Sales reps of a cloud service provider use Sales Dialer to call prospects from Salesforce. A sales manager is concerned about the low performance of the sales reps who work under him. He would like to improve their selling techniques.

Sales Dialer can be used by sales managers to monitor the calls of users who are one level below them in the role hierarchy. They can identify the strengths and weaknesses of their reps from the 'Monitor' tab in the call panel by silently listening to their interactions. Based on the same, they can provide personalized coaching to improve their sales performance
Suggest solution: A sales rep often uses Sales Dialer to call customers and prospects. She would like to refer back to important conversations in order to improve his selling techniques

Calls made and received using Sales Dialer can be recorded from a button in the call panel. The sales rep can refer back to recorded calls to identify any weaknesses which can be eliminated to improve selling techniques.

Suggest solution: Sales Dialer is currently being used by the sales agents of an organization, but its Sales Director would like them to use a separate business line to make and receive calls. However, he would also like them to get all the benefits of using Sales Dialer.

The Call Bridge feature can be utilized by sales agents to make and receive calls using their company phone. It allows receiving all the benefits of using Sales Dialer while using a separate business line

Suggest solution: A sales rep is currently working on an opportunity. His sales manager would like him to work together with two internal sales users and a partner user associated with a partner organization. All users in the company use Lightning Experience
The partner user and the two internal sales users can be included in an Opportunity Team in Lightning Experience to allow them to work together on the opportunity.

Suggest solution: A sales rep in an organization that uses Lightning Experience needs to create an opportunity that includes several products and a product support subscription. She has just processed a similar opportunity the previous day
The sales rep can open the opportunity she created the previous day and use the 'Clone with Related' button to clone the opportunity along with the related opportunity products and line item schedule
Suggest solution: The Sales Director of a company would like to view an overview of the sales performance of the company during the current fiscal quarter.
A sales executive dashboard can be downloaded from the AppExchange. It would show key metrics including KPIs related to the sales performance of the company during the current fiscal quarter

Suggest solution: Cosmic Enterprises would like to identify high-quality leads in Salesforce using lead scoring. However, the calculation of lead scores should be based on the company’s successful conversion patterns.
Einstein Lead Scoring can be utilized. It uses data science and machine learning to score leads based on the company’s successful conversion patterns

Suggest solution: Cosmic Travels recently started using Sales Cloud. It would like to identify how likely each opportunity is to get closed by assigning a score to the opportunity based on positive and negative influences.
Einstein Opportunity Scoring can be used. It uses positive and negative factors as well as objects such as Product, Quote, and Price Book to give each opportunity a score from 1 to 99.
Suggest solution: Sales reps of Cosmic Solutions would like to view important updates related to leads and opportunity as soon as they log in.

A standard Lightning component called ‘Assistant’ can be added to the Home Page for this use case. It shows important updates related to leads and opportunities, such as overdue opportunities and leads assigned today
{{c1::Leads}} are used to track prospects in Salesforce. After qualifying the {{c1::lead}} records, they can be converted into {{c2::accounts}}, {{c3::contacts}}, and/or {{c4::opportunities}}.
{{c1::Campaigns}} can be used to store marketing efforts that are used to obtain leads and store them in Salesforce.
A {{c1::Lead}} is a person that may be interested in an organization's products or services, may also be known as a {{c2::Prospect}}.
Lead {{c1::Status}} contains the Lead process values defined for the Lead Life Cycle, e.g Open, Contacted, Unqualified, Qualified (Converted).
Lead {{c1::Source}} is where the Lead originated from; could be: Web, Phone, Cold Calls etc.
Lead {{c1::Owner}} is the user or queue that owns the Lead.
By default, {{c1::Last Name}}, {{c1::Company}}, and {{c1::Lead Status}} fields need to be populated before a Lead record can be created.
Lead {{c1::Queues}} are a place to store Leads before they have an owner
{{c1::Assignment Rules}} can be used to direct leads to different queues based on defined criteria.
A Queue is accessed via a {{c1::List View}} that is automatically generated when the queue is created.
Users can use the {{c1::‘Accept’}} button to take ownership of a Lead in a queue
Leads can be checked for duplicates with the Potential Duplicates lightning component. Any possible duplicates are displayed and up to {{c1::3}} Leads can be merged.
To merge multiple leads you must be Lead {{c1::Owner}}, Lead {{c1::Owner Manager}} or {{c1::System Administrator}}.
{{c1::Potential Duplicate}} lightning component can be added to the object page. When a duplicate has been detected, an option to merge records will be displayed.
Lead {{c1::Actions}} are just simply quick {{c1::actions}} to add new or update existing Lead records directly from the List View.

The {{c1::‘Convert’}} button on the Lead can be used to convert a Lead. It will create a {{c2::Contact}} from the Lead. It will create and associate the {{c2::Contact}} with a newly created {{c3::Account}} based on the Lead company (or if a similar {{c3::Account}} already exists, it will allow to select). Optionally create a follow up {{c4::Task}}. Optionally create an {{c5::Opportunity}}.
When {{c1::Person Accounts}} is enabled in an org, the Company field on the Lead object becomes optional.
Hiding the {{c1::opportunity}} section is useful when sales reps are not required to convert leads into opportunities.
The Lead {{c1::Workspace}} is the record page and used to view all information related to a Lead.
A number of Lead Assignment rules can be setup but only {{c1::one}} can be active at one time.
{{c1::Web-to-Lead}} is used to save Lead details from a company website to a Salesforce Organization.  Limited to {{c2::500}} new leads per day
It is possible to require {{c1::'reCAPTCHA Verification'}} to reduce spam and reject leads without verification.

{{c1::Campaigns}} are used to store and track information about direct mail programs, seminars, print ads, email, and other kinds of marketing activities in Salesforce. {{c1::Campaigns}} can be created to market directly to leads so that prospects can be turned into sales opportunities.

{{c1::Leads}}, {{c1::contacts,}} and {{c1::accounts}} can be associated with campaigns in Salesforce. It is possible to organize campaigns into {{c2::hierarchies}} to analyze what works best for the company's sales.
In Campaigns, the {{c1::‘Marketing User’}} permission is needed on the user record to access campaign functionality.
Campaign execution takes place outside of Salesforce, and Salesforce has a mass email limit of {{c1::5000}} per day. An AppExchange app can be used to send more mass emails.
In Lightning Experience, {{c1::Path}} can be used by marketing users to manage the lifecycle of campaigns.

Leads, contacts, or accounts can be added to a campaign as a {{c1::‘Member’}}. Each campaign defines its member ‘status’ values to track the status of the member: {{c2::Sent}}, {{c2::Attending}}, {{c2::Declined}}.
Sending an email to multiple campaign members can be done using {{c1::Campaign List Emails}}
A campaign {{c1::hierarchy}} can be used to link related campaigns. There can be up to {{c2::5}} levels and an unlimited number of sibling campaigns.
Campaign {{c1::Influence}} is a feature that helps the organization associate their marketing efforts to match with the opportunity record results
Campaign {{c1::influence models}} can be created to attribute revenue across multiple campaigns.
The {{c1::effectiveness}} of a campaign is directly linked to the number of successful opportunities.
Campaigns can be analyzed from pre-made campaign reports available in the {{c1::Sales and Marketing Reports}} folder
What is a Kanban view?

It shows Opportunities of one record type on a board with columns for each sales stage. The totals for each stage are displayed, and Opportunities can be moved between stages by dragging and dropping.
What can be used to send alerts regarding opportunities with large amounts

Big Deal alerts can be used to send a notification to selected users 
about an opportunity. The alert can be triggered from a workflow rule, 
flow, or process and criteria defined.
How does Salesforce support estimating future revenue?

Customizable and Collaborative (now default) forecasting. Values are 
displayed in forecast categories (mapped from Opportunity stages) by 
Product family, revenue, quantity or both.
What are Opportunity Teams?

Records multiple users that work together on an Opportunity. The role 
and access level can be specified for each user. Each user can specify a
 default team that can be added automatically to an Opportunity.
What are Opportunity Sales Stages?

A way to track the lifecycle of an Opportunity from open to closed. 
Stages are mapped to a type, probability and forecast category.
What is a Custom Opportunity Split?

A feature to define up to 6 splits between Opportunity team members on 
any currency field, for example defining how profit is split.
What are Opportunity Splits?

Splits revenue or other currency field values among the Opportunity 
team. When enabled, a revenue split (must total 100%) and an overlay 
split (doesn’t have to total 100%) is added.
How do Quotes and Syncing work?

Multiple quotes can be associated with an Opportunity with one marked as
 the ‘syncing’ quote. Changes to Opportunity Products or quote Products 
are kept in ‘sync’ for the ‘syncing’ quote.
What are Account Insights?

Account Insights are preprocessed articles related to an Account, 
Industry or Executives that are displayed on the Account Details page or
 Home page, in Lightning Experience once enabled.
What is a Quantity Product Schedule?
